climbs.name: Running a Rig
climbs.fa: (TR) Troy Mayr, et al, 1988; First Lead: Nick Rhodes, November 2021

content.description: Short, but a steep and thin crack.
content.protection: TR.  Can belay at the tree where Deception Pillar and Brilliant Disguise end.
content.location:
Top of the right hand side of Deception Pillar. Approach by downclimbing the upper section of

Short Story

.

content.description:
This is a good route with hard, steep, and tricky climbing on it.

Climb past a couple of bolts to the start of the steep section. There may still be doubled bolts protecting the crux if the route has not had it's bolts replaced yet. A difficult sequence gets one to the large knob that is the obvious goal. A somewhat unusual sequence of moves is encountered at the last bolt.

Continue up the second pitch of

Deception Pillar

.
content.protection: Bolts on pitch 1.  Thin to 2" and slings for pitch 2 (Deception Pillar).
content.location: Lower right side of Deception Pillar.

climbs.name: Brilliant Disguise
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Troy Mayr, Charles Cole, Charlie Peterson, 1987

content.description: Good climbing.  Climb up and left to a flake.  Above the flake follow four bolts onto easier knob and face climbing above.  Stay right of the second pitch of Deception Pillar.
content.protection: Bolts.  Gear for first belay and possibly the flake at the start of the pitch.  Belay at tree.
content.location:
Begin the route from a ledge 40' up

Short Story

(scrambling).

climbs.name: Deception Pillar
climbs.fa: Pat Callis and Larry Harrell, July 1968

content.description: Pitch 1 (5.9) has some fairly nice finger jamming (crux), liebacking, and then face climbing up to a large belay ledge.  Pitch 2 is an easy chimney.
